an9.41:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.
an9.41:1.2: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Uruvelakappa for alms.
an9.41:1.3: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
an9.41:1.4: “Ānanda, you stay right here, while I plunge deep into the Great Wood for the day’s abiding.”
an9.41:1.6: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Great Wood and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s abiding.
an9.41:2.1: The householder Tapussa went up to Venerable Ānanda, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an9.41:3.1: “Bhante Ānanda, we are laypeople who partake in sensuality. We enjoy sensuality, we are fond of it and are pleased by it.
an9.41:3.2: To us laypeople who partake in sensuality, who enjoy it, are fond of it, and are pleased by it, renunciation seems like an abyss.
an9.41:3.3: I have heard that in this teaching and training there are very young bhikkhus whose minds leap at renunciation; their minds, seeing it as peaceful, are confident, settled, and liberated in it.
an9.41:3.4: It is precisely renunciation that is the dividing line between the multitude and the bhikkhus in this teaching and training.”
an9.41:4.1: “Householder, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
an9.41:4.2: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.
an9.41:4.3: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
an9.41:5.2: Then Venerable Ānanda together with Tapussa went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Venerable Ānanda told him what had happened.
an9.41:7.2: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought,
an9.41:7.4: But my mind didn’t see renunciation as peaceful, and so it didn’t leap at it, and wasn’t confident, settled, and liberated in it.
an9.41:7.6: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind doesn’t see renunciation as peaceful, and so it doesn’t leap at it, and isn’t confident, settled, and liberated in it?’
an9.41:7.8: ‘I haven’t seen the woe in sensuality, and I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the value of renunciation, and I haven’t fostered that.
an9.41:7.9: That is why my mind doesn’t see renunciation as peaceful, and so doesn’t leap at it, and isn’t confident, settled, and liberated in it.’
an9.41:7.11: ‘Suppose that, having seen the woe in sensuality, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, having realized the value of renunciation, I were to foster that.
an9.41:7.12: It’s possible that, seeing it as peaceful, my mind would leap at renunciation, and be confident, settled, and liberated in it.’
an9.41:7.13: And so, after some time, having seen the woe in sensuality, I cultivated that, and having realized the value of renunciation, I fostered that.
an9.41:7.14: Then, seeing it as peaceful, my mind leapt at renunciation, and was confident, settled, and liberated in it.
an9.41:7.15: And so, quite separated from sensuality, separated from detrimental phenomena, with thinking and with pondering, with joy and ease born of separation, I abided having entered upon the first jhāna.
an9.41:7.16: As I abided in that way, perceptions and attentions connected with sensuality beset me, and that was an affliction for me.
an9.41:7.17: Suppose unease would arise for someone who is at ease; that would be an affliction for them.
an9.41:7.18: In the same way, perceptions and attentions connected with sensuality beset me, and that was an affliction for me.

an9.41:16.1: As long as I hadn’t entered upon and withdrawn from these nine progressive attainments of abiding in both forward and reverse order, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
an9.41:16.2: But when I had entered upon and withdrawn from these nine progressive attainments of abiding in both forward and reverse order, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
an9.41:16.4: ‘My liberation of mind is unshakable; this is my last birth; now there will be no renewal of being.’
